title: Who is studying science? An analysis of patterns in the recruitment, training and employment of scientists.
abstractText:
More science is now being taught to more students at school than at any time in history. However, falling A-level science entries, the closure of several university science and mathematics departments, poor career opportunities and educational experiences and narrow skills development, all point to a crisis in education and training in the sciences. This ‘science problem’ both threatens the place of the UK as a knowledge-based economy and foreshadows an impending crisis in the provision of scientifically educated workers and scientifically literate citizens. Much of the focus of the ‘science problem’ has been on long-standing concerns about how science is taught in schools. Less attention has been devoted to the undergraduate student experience and the reasons learners give for continuing along a career trajectory that will end in them becoming professional scientists and technicians. In this project we will combine secondary data analysis with a survey and interviews with undergraduate students, to examine these three research questions:

  • What are the long-term patterns of participation in science and science-related courses at the end of compulsory schooling?
  • What influences undergraduate students’ decisions to pursue a career in science?
  • What happens to science graduates once they leave higher education?
